module.title: Should feminine nouns and their adjectives be slenderised after prepositions?
Am bu chòir ainmean a bhith air an sèimheachadh anns an tuiseal ghinideach?
module.p: The following prepositions govern a noun in the dative case –

ul.li: à out of, aig at, air on, ann an in, bho from, de of, do to, fo under, gu to, le with, mu about, ri to, ro before, tro through

module.p: In traditional Gaelic, a feminine singular noun governed by one of these prepositions was slenderised (where possible) eg.

ul.li: uinneag a window → tro uinneig through a window, tron uinneig through the window
coinneamh a meeting → aig coinneimh at a meeting, aig a’ choinneimh at the meeting

module.p: In addition, any adjectives following these nouns were slenderised in sympathy eg.

ul.li: uinneag mhòr ghorm a big blue window → tro uinneig mhòir ghuirm through a big blue window, tron uinneig mhòir ghuirm through the big blue window
coinneamh cudromach an important meeting → aig coinneimh chudromaich at an important meeting, aig a’ choinneimh chudromaich at the important meeting

module.p: However, in contemporary vernacular Gaelic, there is a tendency to avoid this kind of slenderisation, especially in the absence of an article eg.
Neither of these usages should be considered ungrammatical at this time –

ul.li: If you are aiming for a more informal, conversational or modern style, avoid slenderisation of feminine nouns and their adjectives after prepositions.
If you are aiming for a more formal, literary or traditional style, embrace slenderisation of feminine nouns and their adjectives after prepositions.

module.p: See also – dative singular forms of common nouns
Note finally that the following prepositions do not govern nouns in the dative case, so rules regarding slenderisation are different –

ul.li: chun to, far off, rè during, tarsainn across, fad throughout (genitive)
